questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit due to severe sepsis caused by a ruptured abdominal abscess. She has been receiving high-dose intravenous corticosteroids for hypotension management over the past three days. On examination, she is alert but appears critically ill. Laboratory results are as follows:

  • TSH: 1.2 µU/mL (normal range: 0.4–4.0 µU/mL)
  • Free T4: 1.1 ng/dL (normal range: 0.8–1.8 ng/dL)
  • Free T3: 0.6 pg/mL (normal range: 2.0–4.4 pg/mL)

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Euthyroid sick syndrome

 

In severe systemic illness (like sepsis), thyroid function tests often show low T3, normal/low T4, and normal/low TSH due to impaired peripheral conversion of T4 → T3 and altered hypothalamic-pituitary regulation. Here, Free T3 is low, Free T4 is normal, and TSH is normal → classic for euthyroid sick syndrome.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis: Typically shows elevated TSH with low T4/T3, along with autoimmune antibody positivity.
 

Option B. Drug-induced hypothyroidism: Drugs like amiodarone, lithium, interferon-α cause true hypothyroidism with ↑ TSH and ↓ T4.
 

Option C. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Characterized by ↑ TSH with normal T4/T3, not seen in this case.

choices.text: Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high
Cortisol normal, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal
Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal
Cortisol high, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and dizziness upon standing. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her mother was recently diagnosed with hypothyroidism. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg supine and 80/50 mm Hg standing. Laboratory results reveal the following:

 

Sodium 129 meq/l 

 

Potassium 5.9 meq/l 

 

Chloride 100 meq/l 

 

Bicarbonate 21 meq/l 

 

Creatinine 1.4 mg/dl 

 

BUN 38 mg/dl 

 

Which of the following in circulating hormone levels are expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

 

This patient has primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) indicated by fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Cortisol and aldosterone are both low, leading to hypotension and volume depletion. Compensatory mechanisms increase ADH and norepinephrine to maintain blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol normal, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal: Cortisol would be low, not normal, and compensatory hormones would be elevated.

 

Option C. Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal: ADH rises in response to hypotension and hyponatremia; norepinephrine is also elevated.

 

Option D. Cortisol high, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high: Cortisol is not high in adrenal insufficiency; high cortisol would suppress ADH and norepinephrine.

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents for evaluation of her low bone density noted during a routine screening. She is started on oral risedronate to address her bone loss. What is the primary mechanism through which this medication improves bone density?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased osteoclast apoptosis

 

Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that binds to bone and induces osteoclast apoptosis, reducing bone resorption and thereby increasing bone density. Its main effect is antiresorptive, not anabolic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of osteoblast activity: Risedronate does not directly stimulate osteoblast activity.

 

Option B. Decreased stimulation of RANK ligand (RANKL): It does not affect RANKL signaling directly; it targets osteoclasts.

 

Option C. Increased intestinal calcium absorption: It does not increase intestinal calcium absorption; that is the action of vitamin D.

choices.text: Activation of lactotrophs by antithyroid peroxidase antibodies
Binding of dopamine receptors by antithyroid peroxidase antibodies
Inhibition of dopamine release by TSH
Stimulation of lactotrophs by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to a 4-month history of amenorrhea. She has also had a whitish nipple discharge from both breasts. The patient has taken several pregnancy tests at home that have been negative. She has also had increased fatigue, depressed mood, and weight gain over this time. The patient has had no headaches or vision changes. On physical examination, there is thinning of the outer third of the eyebrows. The thyroid is enlarged and nontender to palpation. The skin appears dry.  Her thyroxine (T4) levels are low, TSH is elevated, and antithyroid peroxidase antibodies are positive. Prolactin levels are 30 ng/ml. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism causing this patient's elevated prolactin level?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stimulation of lactotrophs by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)


This patient has primary hypothyroidism, indicated by low T4, high TSH, positive anti-TPO antibodies, and classic symptoms. Elevated TRH in response to low thyroid hormone stimulates lactotrophs, causing mild hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of lactotrophs by antithyroid peroxidase antibodies: Antithyroid antibodies do not directly activate lactotrophs.

 

Option B. Binding of dopamine receptors by antithyroid peroxidase antibodies: They do not bind dopamine receptors.

 

Option C. Inhibition of dopamine release by TSH: TSH does not inhibit dopamine release; TRH is the main stimulator of prolactin

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD for follow-up of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is taking the maximum dose of metformin. Her hemoglobinA1c is 7.7%. Blood pressure is 134/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 72/min. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Family history is significant for osteoporosis in mother. The results of other laboratory tests are normal. After discussion, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor is added to the patient's drug regimen. Which of the following is the most likely additional effect of the newly prescribed medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased blood pressure
 

SGLT-2 inhibitors lower blood glucose by promoting glycosuria and also cause mild diuresis, leading to a reduction in blood pressure. They also contribute to modest weight loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased bone mineral density: They do not increase bone mineral density; some may slightly decrease it.

 

Option C. Increased fluid retention: They cause fluid loss, not retention.

 

Option D. Increased postprandial satiety: They do not significantly affect postprandial satiety.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and reports recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. His wife mentions that he has been trying a new "natural" supplement along with his prescribed insulin. On arrival, his blood glucose is 45 mg/dL. Laboratory tests reveal high serum C-peptide levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sulfonylurea overdose


High C-peptide with hypoglycemia indicates endogenous insulin overproduction, which is characteristic of a sulfonylurea overdose. Sulfonylureas stimulate pancreatic beta cells to release insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Exogenous insulin in supplement: Exogenous insulin causes low C-peptide levels.

 

Option C. Insulinoma: Insulinoma can cause high C-peptide, but sudden onset after a supplement suggests drug-induced hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. GLP-1 agonist: GLP-1 agonists rarely cause severe hypoglycemia and usually require concurrent insulin or sulfonylurea.

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the effect of parathyroid hormone (PTH) on bone remodeling. Half of the study subjects receive intermittent PTH injections and the other half receive a continuous infusion of PTH. The results show that the effects on bone metabolism of intermittent PTH injections are different from those of continuous infusion. Which of the following is most likely to be the predominant bone effect with intermittent injections?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stimulation of osteoblast activity


Intermittent PTH administration has an anabolic effect on bone by directly stimulating osteoblast activity, increasing bone formation and improving bone density.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of RANKL: Continuous PTH, not intermittent, increases RANKL and osteoclast activity.

 

Option B. Increased levels of osteoprotegerin: Osteoprotegerin levels are not significantly increased by intermittent PTH.

 

Option C. Osteoclast apoptosis: Intermittent PTH does not primarily induce osteoclast apoptosis.

choices.text: Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland
Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and insomnia over the past 4 months. Her vital signs are blood pressure 140/85 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and regular. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies reveal decreased serum TSH and elevated free thyroxine (T4) levels. Methimazole is initiated as treatment. Which of the following processes is most likely inhibited by this treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coupling of iodotyrosine

 

Methimazole inhibits thyroid peroxidase, preventing the coupling of iodotyrosines to form T3 and T4, thereby reducing thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iodide uptake by the thyroid gland: Methimazole does not inhibit iodide uptake; that is the function of the sodium-iodide symporter.

 

Option C. Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3: It does not affect peripheral conversion of T4 to T3; drugs like propranolol or amiodarone influence that.

 

Option D. Colloid production: Colloid production is not directly affected by methimazole.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to hair loss.  The patient has fatigue and decreased libido, and her menstrual cycles have not returned since her delivery 8 months ago. The thyroid is nontender. Laboratory results show decreased serum TSH and free thyroxine (T4) levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary hypothyroidism 

 

This patient has secondary hypothyroidism due to pituitary insufficiency, indicated by low TSH despite low T4. The failure of TSH to rise differentiates it from primary thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis: Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis usually shows high TSH in hypothyroid phase.

 

Option B. Graves disease: Graves disease causes hyperthyroidism, not low T4.

 

Option C. Postpartum thyroiditis: Postpartum thyroiditis usually shows transient hyperthyroidism first; low TSH with low T4 is less common.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman comes to the AIIMS OPD due to a 6.8-kg weight gain over the last few months. The patient also has experienced weakness and cannot lift weights that she was able to lift before the onset of her symptoms. On examination, blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and pulse is 88/min and regular. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Dark terminal hair is present on the lower abdomen. Fasting laboratory results are as follows: 

 

Sodium-142 mEq/L

Potassium-3.6 mEq/L

Chloride-98 mEq/L

Bicarbonate-28 mEq/L

Calcium-9.2 mg/dL

TSH-2.2 mlU/L (N-0.5 to 5.0 mIU/L)

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

 

The patient has features suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome (weight gain, hypertension, proximal muscle weakness, and hirsutism). The overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test is the first-line screening test to confirm endogenous cortisol excess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early-morning cortisol level: Early-morning cortisol can vary and is less sensitive for screening Cushing’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Serum ACTH level: Serum ACTH is useful after confirming hypercortisolism to differentiate ACTH-dependent vs independent causes.

 

Option D. Cosyntropin test: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is mainly used to evaluate adrenal insufficiency, not Cushing’s.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway?

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Activation of PKA
  3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

Upon ligand binding, the GPCR activates adenylate cyclase, which converts ATP to cAMP. cAMP then activates protein kinase A (PKA), which phosphorylates target proteins to produce cellular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incorrect sequence: PKA cannot activate before cAMP formation.

 

Option C. Phosphorylation occurs after PKA activation, not before.

 

Option D. This order is completely reversed and physiologically incorrect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation, he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na = 124mg / d*L creatinine= 2.8 mg%, blood sugar= 112 mg/dL, blood urea= 24 mg/dL, serum osmolality= 255 mOsm, urine osmolality= 120 mOsm, 24-hour urinary sodium= 110, and BP = 150/90 mmHg. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

The patient has SIADH secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma, indicated by hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, inappropriately concentrated urine, and high urinary sodium. This is a classic paraneoplastic manifestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diuretic induced hyponatremia: Diuretic-induced hyponatremia usually presents with volume depletion, which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Diabetes insipidus causes hypernatremia with dilute urine, opposite to this case.

 

Option D. Pseudohyponatremia: Pseudohyponatremia is rare and associated with severe hyperlipidemia or hyperproteinemia, not applicable here.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

DKA is diagnosed with hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis (pH <7.3), and elevated anion gap. Serum potassium is usually normal or elevated initially due to insulin deficiency and acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/Dl: Glucose >250 mg/dL is a standard criterion for DKA.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: pH <7.3 indicates metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: Anion gap >12 confirms high-anion-gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to confusion, abdominal pain, and vomiting for the past two days. Her parents report that she has been excessively thirsty and urinating frequently over the last few weeks. On examination, her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.2°C (99°F), pulse 110/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 28/min. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:

 

  • Glucose 320 mg/dL
  • Sodium 132 meq/l
  • Potassium 5.2 meq/l
  • Bicarbonate 12 meq/l
  • Arterial pH 7.25
  • Urinalysis: Positive for urine and ketones

 

Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Islet leukocytic infiltration

 

This patient has type 1 diabetes with DKA, where autoimmune islet leukocytic infiltration destroys beta cells, leading to insulin deficiency and ketosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive caloric intake does not directly cause DKA.

 

Option B. HLA polymorphisms increase susceptibility but are not the direct cause of acute DKA.

 

Option C. Beta-cell amyloid deposition is associated with type 2 diabetes, not type 1.

questions.text: An elderly patient with type Il diabetes presents with altered sensorium. He has not been eating or drinking well for the past few weeks. There are no complaints of nausea or abdominal pain. His blood sugar level is 800 mg/dL. All of the following are true regarding this condition, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HAGMA is associated

 

This patient likely has hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), characterized by extreme hyperglycemia, high serum osmolality, dehydration, and absence of significant ketosis or HAGMA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L: Serum osmolality is markedly elevated in HHS.

 

Option B. High mortality is associated: Mortality is higher in HHS compared to DKA.

 

Option D. Pre-renal azotemia is seen: Pre-renal azotemia occurs due to severe dehydration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, having lost her newborn, is producing breast milk, which risks developing into a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which drug can prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, suppresses prolactin secretion and prevents lactation, reducing the risk of milk stasis and breast abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone does not suppress lactation.

 

Option C. Cabergoline: Bromocriptine can suppress lactation but cabergoline is preferred due to fewer side effects.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide increases prolactin and promotes lactation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myxedema coma

 

The patient has myxedema coma, indicated by severe hypothyroidism, altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head injury: Head injury does not explain hypothyroid features.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock lacks non-pitting edema and hypothermia typical of myxedema.

 

Option C. Adrenal insufficiency: Adrenal insufficiency presents with hypotension but without bradycardia and hypothermia specific to myxedema.

choices.text: Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin Il on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells

questions.text: Which of the following act via the IP3-DAG Messenger System?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle

 

Angiotensin II (AT1 receptor) and vasopressin via V1 receptor activate the IP3-DAG pathway, leading to calcium release and smooth muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angiotensin II on vascular smooth muscle and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells: Vasopressin via V2 receptor works through cAMP, not IP3-DAG.

 

Option C. Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle: Angiotensin II does not act on epithelial cells for IP3-DAG signaling.

 

Option D. Angiotensin II on epithelial cells and Vasopressin via V2 receptor on epithelial cells: Both act on epithelial cells or V2 receptor via cAMP, not IP3-DAG.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and dizziness for the past few weeks. His investigations reveal hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. He also complains of skin changes as seen in the image below (A before 3 yrs; B,C,D at presentation). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insulin resistance

 

The clinical images (C and D) show hyperpigmentation and thickened skin over the hands and palms, which is characteristic of acanthosis nigricans. This skin finding is most commonly associated with insulin resistance, seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Does not cause characteristic acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Decreased androgen: Not associated with the shown skin changes.

 

Option D. Decreased cortisol: Usually leads to diffuse hyperpigmentation (Addison's disease) but not the specific thickening seen here.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure was 146/91 mm Hg at his appointment 1 month ago; subsequent home blood pressure measurements have ranged from 135/83 mm Hg to 156/96 mm Hg. His blood pressure today is 141/85 mm Hg.  Pharmacotherapy with lisinopril is initiated. Administration of this drug is most likely to result in decreased activity of which of the following sections of a normal adrenal gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that decreases aldosterone secretion by blocking the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Aldosterone is produced in the zona glomerulosa, which corresponds to area B on the adrenal gland histology image. Reduced stimulation by angiotensin II results in decreased activity in this zone.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. A: Capsule, not hormone-producing.

 

Option C. C: Zona fasciculata—mainly produces cortisol.

 

Option D. D: Zona reticularis—mainly produces androgens.

 

E= adrenal medulla which produces Cathecholamines

questions.text: An 65-year-old female patient, with a recent history of a distal radius fracture, undergoes an assessment of bone mineral density. A DEXA scan shows a T-score of -2.6. Which of the following medications is not used for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cinacalcet

 

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic used to treat hyperparathyroidism, not osteoporosis. The other agents are antiresorptive or anabolic medications used to improve bone density.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zoledronate: Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate that reduces bone resorption.

 

Option B. Denosumab: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANKL, reducing osteoclast activity.

 

Option D. Romosozumab: Romosozumab is a sclerostin inhibitor that increases bone formation.

choices.text: Binding of activated receptors to DNA to modify transcription

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the OPD for evaluation of short stature. Her parents have noticed that she bears little resemblance to her 2 older siblings. Other findings include low-set ears, a high arched palate, a webbed neck, and cubitus valgus. Chromosomal analysis reveals a 45, XO karyotype. The patient is started on a medication to improve growth and normalize her height. Which of the following intracellular pathways is stimulated by the medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) JAK-STAT pathway

 

The patient has Turner syndrome and is treated with growth hormone, which acts via the JAK-STAT pathway to stimulate IGF-1 production and promote growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binding of activated receptors to DNA to modify transcription: DNA-binding receptors are typical of steroid hormones, not growth hormone.

 

Option B. Cyclic AMP-Protein kinase A pathway: cAMP-PKA pathway is used by hormones like ACTH or TSH.

 

Option C. Diacylglycerol-Protein kinase C pathway: DAG-PKC pathway is utilized by IP3/DAG signaling hormones.

choices.text: Decreased conversion of T4 to T3

questions.text: A 52-year-old, post-menopausal woman comes to the OPD for a follow-up appointment. Six months ago, the patient was evaluated for recurrent, brief episodes of excessive warmth and sweating, which were interfering with her usual activities. Thyroid hormone levels were normal, and the patient was subsequently diagnosed with menopausal hot flashes. Treatment with estrogen-containing hormone replacement therapy was begun with significant symptom improvement. Which of the following most likely occurred in this patient as a result of her medication use?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased total T4 level

 

Estrogen therapy increases thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), leading to an increase in total T4 levels, while free T4 remains normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased conversion of T4 to T3: Estrogen does not significantly affect T4 to T3 conversion.

 

Option B. Decreased thyroid iodine uptake: Iodine uptake by the thyroid is unaffected.

 

Option C. Decreased TSH level: TSH levels remain largely unchanged if free T4 is normal.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD with fatigue. He has hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes complicated by nephropathy and peripheral neuropathy. His renal function has declined steadily over the last few years.  On the graph below, area "C" shows the normal relationship between serum concentrations of free calcium and parathyroid hormone. Which of the following areas most likely represents this patient's current metabolic state?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In a patient with chronic kidney disease and declining renal function, secondary hyperparathyroidism develops due to phosphate retention and decreased vitamin D activation, causing low serum calcium and high parathyroid hormone levels. On the graph, area A represents this state—high parathyroid hormone with low serum calcium.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. B: High calcium and PTH—seen in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. C: Normal relationship—healthy state.

 

Option D. E: Low calcium and low PTH—not typical in CKD with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

choices.text: Acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland
Dissection of the internal carotid artery
lschemic necrosis of the pituitary gland

questions.text: 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a severe, sudden-onset headache with loss of vision in bilateral temporal fields that started an hour ago. The patient reports that he has had mild headaches and decreased libido over the past 3 months.  Shortly after being admitted to the hospital, he becomes acutely hypotensive and loses consciousness. Which of the following is most likely to be found on autopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland

 

The patient likely had pituitary apoplexy, which presents as sudden headache, visual loss, hypotension, and hypopituitarism. Autopsy would reveal acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bleeding within the putamen: Putaminal hemorrhage causes focal neurological deficits but not the endocrine features.

 

Option C. Dissection of the internal carotid artery: Carotid dissection presents with stroke or Horner’s syndrome, not hypopituitarism.

 

Option D. Ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland: Ischemic necrosis (Sheehan’s syndrome) develops postpartum, not acutely in this male patient.

choices.text: Metformin is contraindicated in all stages of CKD
Pioglitazone is avoided as it is exclusively metabolized by kidneys
Glipizide can be used in renal disease
Linagliptin can be used only after dose reduction

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus. She has a history of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following statement is correct about the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glipizide can be used in renal disease

 

Glipizide is metabolized by the liver and can be safely used in patients with renal disease, unlike some other sulfonylureas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin is contraindicated in all stages of CKD: Metformin is contraindicated only in advanced CKD, not all stages.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone is avoided as it is exclusively metabolized by kidneys: Pioglitazone is metabolized in the liver, not kidneys.

 

Option D. Linagliptin can be used only after dose reduction: Linagliptin does not require dose adjustment in CKD.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alogliptin

 

Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, which increases levels of incretins GIP and GLP-1, thereby reducing glucagon and lowering blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voglibose: Voglibose inhibits carbohydrate absorption, not incretins.

 

Option C. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog, not a DPP-4 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, not an oral DPP-4 inhibitor.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? 

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR 
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy 
  5. ECG 
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

For a patient presenting with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar 205 mg/dl), the appropriate investigations include:

 

i) HbA1c: to assess long-term glycemic control.
 

ii) Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR): to screen for diabetic nephropathy.
 

iv) Fundoscopy: to evaluate for diabetic retinopathy.
 

v) ECG: to assess for cardiovascular risk factors common in diabetes.

 

Incorrect statement

 

iii) Echocardiography: not routinely indicated initially unless cardiac symptoms are present.
 

vi) Serum protein electrophoresis: unrelated to diabetes evaluation.

choices.text: GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size low
GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged
GH low, IGF-1 unchanged, adenoma size low
GH unchanged, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the OPD following transsphenoidal resection of a growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma. Three months ago, the patient was diagnosed with acromegaly. MRI of the pituitary showed a 14 mm sellar mass pressing on the optic chiasm and extending into the right cavernous sinus. The surgeon was able to only partially resect the pituitary mass because of the extension into the right cavernous sinus. Medical therapy for acromegaly with octreotide is planned. Which of the following changes are likely to occur following octreotide treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size low 

 

Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue that suppresses growth hormone (GH) secretion from pituitary adenomas. This leads to a decrease in both GH and insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels. Additionally, octreotide often causes tumor shrinkage, resulting in decreased adenoma size.

 

Other Options:


Option B. GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged: Adenoma size usually decreases with octreotide treatment.

 

Option C. GH low, IGF-1 unchanged, adenoma size low: IGF-1 levels typically decrease along with GH.

 

Option D. GH unchanged, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged: GH levels decrease first; unchanged GH with low IGF-1 is unlikely.

choices.text: ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low
ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

questions.text: Two days after vaginal delivery of a healthy newborn at term, a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is unable to breastfeed. Her labor was complicated by antepartum hemorrhage and she received two units of packed red blood cells. Her pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of serum findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

This patient presents with inability to breastfeed two days postpartum, hypotension, and a history of significant antepartum hemorrhage with blood transfusions, suggesting postpartum hypopituitarism (Sheehan syndrome).

 

In Sheehan syndrome, ischemic necrosis of the pituitary leads to decreased secretion of anterior pituitary hormones, including ACTH, resulting in secondary adrenal insufficiency with low cortisol levels. Aldosterone secretion is typically preserved because it is regulated mainly by the renin-angiotensin system, not ACTH.

 

Therefore, the most likely serum findings are: ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is usually normal because it is regulated independently of ACTH.

 

Option B. ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is unlikely to be high in this context.

 

Option C. ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low: ACTH would be low due to pituitary failure, not high.

choices.text: Octreotide – Treatment of diarrhea associated with vasoactive intestinal peptide tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs and its indications is matched incorrectly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bromocriptine – Treatment of precocious puberty

 

Bromocriptine is primarily used for hyperprolactinemia and Parkinson’s disease, not precocious puberty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Octreotide – Treatment of diarrhea associated with vasoactive intestinal peptide tumors: Octreotide is correctly indicated for VIPoma-associated diarrhea.

 

Option C. Desmopressin – Treatment of diabetes insipidus: Desmopressin treats central diabetes insipidus.

 

Option D. Leuprolide – Treatment of infertility: Leuprolide is used in assisted reproduction for infertility management.

questions.text:
53-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of increased urinary frequency for the past 4 weeks. He has no burning with urination, urgency, or difficulty initiating urination. He wakes up several times at night to urinate. His mouth feels dry all the time and he drinks fluids almost every hour to alleviate his thirst. The patient's medications include hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine for hypertension. His sister was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus at a young age. His blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 15/min. His body mass index is 32 kg/m². Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Blood glucose-93 mg/dL

 

Serum sodium-150 mEg:L

 

Serum potassium-4.1 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate-24 mEq/L

 

Blood urea nitrogen-21 mg/dL

 

Serum creatinine-1.1 mg/dL

 

Serum uric acid-10.1 mg/dL (N- 3.5-7.2 mg/dL)

 

Serum osmolality-314 mOsm/kg (N- 275 to 295 mOsm/kg)

 

Urine osmolality-124 mOsm/kg (N-500 - 800 mOsm/kg)

 

Which of the following is most consistent with this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Central Diabetes insipidus

 

The patient has central diabetes insipidus, indicated by hypernatremia, high serum osmolality, and inappropriately dilute urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrogenic DI: Nephrogenic DI shows resistance to ADH, often due to drugs or renal disease.

 

Option C. Primary polydipsia: Primary polydipsia presents with hyponatremia and low serum osmolality.

 

Option D. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone: SIADH presents with hyponatremia and concentrated urine.

questions.text: The cells marked in the image of adrenal biopsy are directly activated by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine 

 

The image shows the adrenal medulla, with the arrow indicating chromaffin cells. These cells are directly activated by acetylcholine released from preganglionic sympathetic fibers, leading to secretion of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. ACTH: Stimulates the adrenal cortex, not the medulla.

 

Option C. Angiotensin II: Stimulates aldosterone in the zona glomerulosa of the cortex, not adrenal medulla.

 

Option D. Epinephrine: Is secreted by the adrenal medulla, but does not activate chromaffin cells.

questions.text: 51-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to progressively worsening fatigue, weight gain, and constipation for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows mild, diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland.  Biopsy of this patient's thyroid is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The patients condition is likely suggestive of Hashimoto thyroiditis denoted by option A and symptoms of hypothyroidism such WEIGHT GAIN , CONSTIPATION Ahave been mentioned in the question.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Is Medullary CA thyroid

 

Option C. Suggestive of papillary Ca thyroid

 

Option D. Suggests Amyloidosis inside thyroid

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dl and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
 

Initial management of diabetic ketoacidosis with shock requires rapid fluid resuscitation with normal saline to restore perfusion before insulin therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: Insulin infusion is started after initial fluid resuscitation.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: ABG is useful but not the immediate life-saving step.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: Insulin bolus is not recommended in pediatric DKA due to risk of cerebral edema.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old term boy is brought to the OPD due to increased fussiness and poor weight gain. The patient has several wet diapers per day. His anterior fontanelle is flat and mucous membranes are dry. Laboratory results include the following:

 

Sodium: 148 mEq/L

 

Potassium: 3.5 mEq/L

 

Antidiuretic hormone: increased

 

Urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.002. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide
 

The patient has nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, indicated by hypernatremia, dilute urine, and elevated ADH. Hydrochlorothiazide reduces urine output by inducing mild volume depletion and enhancing proximal tubular water reabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmopressin: Desmopressin is ineffective in nephrogenic DI.

 

Option C. Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone is not indicated.

 

Option D. Insulin: Insulin is unrelated to this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports coarsening of his facial features over several years. In addition, he reports low libido and decreased energy. Physical examination shows frontal bossing and enlarges hands. Which of the following screening tests should be ordered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. IGF-1
 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred screening test for acromegaly, reflecting chronic GH excess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24-Hour UFC: 24-hour UFC screens for Cushing’s syndrome.

 

Option B. S. ACTH: Serum ACTH measures adrenal function, not GH excess.

 

Option C. Fasting GH levels: Fasting GH levels fluctuate and are unreliable for screening.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low PTH
 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism features resistance to PTH, so PTH levels are elevated, not low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium: Low calcium occurs due to end-organ resistance to PTH.

 

Option C. Short 4th and 5th metacarpals: Short 4th and 5th metacarpals are a classic finding (Albright hereditary osteodystrophy).

 

Option D. Short stature: Short stature is commonly seen in this condition.

questions.text: Researchers measure the serum insulin levels of healthy volunteers after equivalent loads of oral (dotted line) and intravenous glucose (solid line). The following curves are observed. Which of the following endogenous substances best explains the difference between the curves?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagon-like peptide-1

 

The graph shows higher insulin secretion after oral glucose (dotted line) compared to intravenous glucose (solid line). This difference is explained by the incretin effect, primarily due to glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), an endogenous hormone released from the intestine after oral glucose that stimulates insulin secretion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Insulin-like growth factor-1: Not directly involved in acute insulin secretion after glucose intake.

 

Option C. Somatostatin: Inhibits insulin secretion, would not account for the increased oral response.

 

Option D. Secretin: Regulates pancreatic secretion but does not significantly affect insulin release in response to glucose.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of blurry vision and fatigue for 2 months. During this period, he has also had occasional bleeding from his gums after brushing his teeth. One month ago, he was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis after returning from an overseas business meeting. His pulse is 118/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 149/91 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips. The tip of the spleen is palpable 1 cm below the left costal margin. Sensory examination of the hands shows paraesthesia. Hemoglobin concentration is 18 g/dL, haematocrit is 65%, leukocytes are 15,000/uL, and platelets are 470,000/uL. His serum erythropoietin concentration is decreased. Activation of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nonreceptor tyrosine kinase

 

JAK2 is a nonreceptor tyrosine kinase mutated in polycythemia vera, causing constitutive activation of signaling pathways that drive uncontrolled proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells independent of erythropoietin.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Receptor tyrosine kinase: These are membrane receptors with intrinsic kinase activity involved in other signaling pathways, not typically mutated in polycythemia vera.

 

Option B. Cytokine receptor: Cytokine receptors lack intrinsic kinase activity and function by associating with kinases like JAK2, so the receptor itself is not the active molecule here.

 

Option C. Antiapoptotic molecule: Polycythemia vera results from increased cell proliferation signaling rather than primary defects in apoptosis regulation.

choices.text: ACTH-producing growth in the pituitary gland
Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells in the renal cortex
Involution of zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue and weakness. She also reports recurrent headaches for 2 years, which have increased in severity and frequency. Her blood pressure is 185/95 mm Hg. Serum studies show a morning renin activity of 130 ng/mL per hour (N=1-4), a morning aldosterone concentration of 60 ng/dL (N=5-30), and a potassium concentration of 2.9 mEq/L. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells in the renal cortex

 

Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells are characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia, a common cause of renovascular hypertension in young females. This leads to renal artery stenosis, resulting in increased renin and aldosterone secretion, causing hypertension and hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ACTH-producing growth in the pituitary gland: Causes Cushing disease, leading to cortisol excess, not elevated renin or aldosterone levels.

 

Option B. Increased urinary excretion of metanephrines: Indicative of pheochromocytoma, which causes episodic hypertension without significant renin or aldosterone elevation.

 

Option D. Involution of zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland: Would decrease aldosterone production, causing hypotension and hyperkalemia, not hypertension or hypokalemia.

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Nelson syndrome occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy due to loss of cortisol feedback inhibition on the pituitary. This leads to enlargement of an existing ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, resulting in high ACTH levels and hyperpigmentation along with possible mass effects causing vision deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum pituitary infarction leading to hypopituitarism, typically without hyperpigmentation or vision loss.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Characterized by primary hyperaldosteronism causing hypertension and hypokalemia, not hyperpigmentation or vision problems.

 

Option D. Addison's disease: Primary adrenal insufficiency causing hyperpigmentation but not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

choices.text: PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased
PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased
PTH decreased, vit D increased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased
PTH decreased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows pitting edema of both ankles. Serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following sets of serum findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased

 

In chronic kidney disease, decreased renal conversion of vitamin D reduces calcium absorption, leading to hypocalcemia. Low calcium and phosphate retention stimulate parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion, causing secondary hyperparathyroidism with increased PTH, low vitamin D, low calcium, and high phosphate levels.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased: Incorrect because calcium is usually decreased, and phosphate is increased due to reduced excretion in CKD.

 

Option C. PTH decreased, vit D increased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased: Incorrect; PTH is typically elevated in CKD to compensate for hypocalcemia, while vitamin D levels are decreased.

 

Option D. PTH decreased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased: Incorrect because decreased PTH does not occur in CKD; PTH is usually elevated in response to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects, including unexplained diarrhea, due to its effects on intestinal absorption and motility. This is a well-known adverse effect often limiting its tolerability.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Primarily causes fluid retention and weight gain, with diarrhea being uncommon.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: May cause nausea and vomiting, but diarrhea is not a typical side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Sulfonylureas like glimepiride commonly cause hypoglycemia and weight gain, not diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following growth hormone analogue that is not used for treatment of GH deficiency but is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tesamorelin

 

Tesamorelin is a synthetic analogue of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) that is specifically used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, a condition characterized by abnormal distribution of body fat in patients with HIV. Tesamorelin reduces visceral adipose tissue and improves the body composition of individuals with this condition. Unlike other growth hormone analogues, Tesamorelin is not primarily used for treating growth hormone deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sermorelin: Sermorelin is a synthetic analogue of GHRH used to diagnose and treat growth hormone deficiency. It is not indicated for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option C. Somatropin: Somatropin is a recombinant form of human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies. It is not used for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It is not used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing hormone analogue used specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, distinguishing it from other growth hormone analogues that are used for treating growth hormone deficiencies.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was referred to a pediatric endocrinologist because of growth retardation. Lab tests showed increased serum growth hormone levels but very low serum levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). Further exams led to the diagnosis of Laron dwarfism. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this boy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mecasermin

 

Mecasermin is recombinant IGF-1 and is the treatment of choice for Laron dwarfism, where GH receptor defects cause low IGF-1 despite high GH levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatropin: Ineffective as GH receptors are defective in Laron dwarfism.

 

Option B. Octreotide: A somatostatin analogue that inhibits GH secretion, not useful here.

 

Option D. Oxandrolone: An anabolic steroid not used for treating growth hormone receptor defects.

questions.text: Sodium iodide symport is present in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pituitary

 

The sodium iodide symporter is responsible for iodide uptake in thyroid, salivary gland, and placenta but is not present in the pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta: Has sodium iodide symporter to actively transport iodide to the fetus.

 

Option C. Salivary gland: Expresses the symporter for iodide concentration in saliva.

 

Option D. Thyroid: The primary site of sodium iodide symporter expression for thyroid hormone synthesis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man developed sudden severe abdominal pain. On physical examination, he had marked abdominal tenderness and guarding. Laboratory studies showed calcium-12.2 mg/dL; phosphorus-2.6 mg/ dL; creatinine, 1.1 mg/dL; and parathyroid hormone-62 pg/mL (normal: 9-60 pg/mL). During surgery, four enlarged parathyroid glands were found and excised, with re-implantation of one half of one gland. After the surgery, his calcium concentration returned to normal. Three years later, he had an episode of upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. An endoscopy and biopsy specimen showed multiple benign gastric ulcerations. Abdominal MRI indicated multiple 1- to 2-cm mass lesions in the pancreas. Which of the following additional neoplasm lesions is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pituitary adenoma

 

This patient likely has Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), characterized by parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and pituitary adenomas. Pituitary adenoma is the common third tumor. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Adrenal pheochromocytoma: Typical of MEN2, not MEN1. 

 

Option B. Endometrial carcinoma: Not associated with MEN syndromes. 

 

Option D. Thyroid medullary carcinoma: Characteristic of MEN2, not MEN1.

questions.text: In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, what is the feature of stage 3 beta cell destruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autoimmune +ve dysglycemic symptomatic

 

Stage 3 represents the clinical onset of Type 1 DM with autoimmune destruction of beta cells, causing dysglycemia and symptoms like polyuria and polydipsia. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Autoimmune +ve Normoglycemic presymptomatic: Represents stage 1 or 2 where glucose levels are still normal. 

 

Option C. Autoimmune -ve Normoglycemic presymptomatic: Incorrect as autoimmunity is present in Type 1 DM. 

 

Option D. Autoimmune -ve dysglycemic presymptomatic: Not typical of Type 1 DM where autoimmunity drives dysglycemia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with headaches, fatigue, visual disturbances. He has sarcoidosis, mild hypercalcemia, and MRI shows mass in hypothalamus and pituitary stalk. Which of the following pituitary hormones is most likely elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolactin 

 

Mass lesions in the hypothalamus or pituitary stalk can disrupt dopamine inhibition, causing elevated prolactin (hyperprolactinemia) which explains the symptoms. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. ACTH: Not typically elevated unless there is an ACTH-secreting tumor. 

 

Option B. Growth hormone: Growth hormone elevation unrelated to this presentation. 

 

Option D. Thyrotropin: Elevated TSH would cause hyperthyroidism, not typically linked here.

questions.text: Identify the correct pair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-Nephrogenic DI

 

On the graph, curve D shows consistently low urine osmolality that does not rise with either water deprivation or desmopressin administration. This pattern is characteristic of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), where the kidneys are unable to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) even after desmopressin, resulting in persistently dilute urine.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B – Normal: Incorrect; B responds to water deprivation and desmopressin but is not normal.

 

Option B. C - Primary polydipsia: C shows improvement with desmopressin, more typical for central DI, not primary polydipsia.

 

Option D. B - Central DI: In central DI, urine osmolality sharply rises only after desmopressin, which matches pattern C, not B.

questions.text: Which function of growth hormone (GH) is specifically mediated via IGF-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antilipolysis

 

The antilipolytic effect of growth hormone is indirectly mediated by IGF-1, which promotes fat storage by opposing GH’s direct lipolytic actions. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Sodium retention: Directly mediated by GH, not IGF-1. 

 

Option B. Lipolysis: A direct effect of GH, independent of IGF-1. 

 

Option C. Reduced insulin sensitivity: Also a direct effect of GH on peripheral tissues, not IGF-1.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is 86/52 mmHg and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says he has been on treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrocortisone 

 

Hydrocortisone replaces both glucocorticoid and some mineralocorticoid activity and is the drug of choice for acute adrenal crisis in Addison’s disease. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Has no mineralocorticoid activity and is less preferred in crisis. 

 

Option B. Fludrocortisone: Only mineralocorticoid, not sufficient alone for adrenal crisis. 

 

Option C. Norepinephrine: A vasopressor; supportive but not a hormone replacement.

choices.text: Early intensive glycemic control has long-term benefits on microvascular and macrovascular complications, even if strict control is not maintained later.
Good glycemic control only in longstanding disease prevents complications.
Early detection and management of dyslipidemia completely prevents metabolic memory.
High HbA1c in longstanding disease has no effect on future complications.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she collapsed suddenly while standing. She also reports left-sided chest pain. Legacy effect (metabolic memory) in diabetes mellitus refers to which of the following observations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early intensive glycemic control has long-term benefits on 

 

microvascular and macrovascular complications, even if strict control is not maintained later. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Good glycemic control only in longstanding disease prevents complications. Incorrect; early glycemic control is key. 

 

Option C. Early detection and management of dyslipidemia completely prevents metabolic memory. Incorrect; metabolic memory involves more factors than dyslipidemia management. 

 

Option C. High HbA1c in longstanding disease has no effect on future complications. Incorrect; it significantly increases risk.

questions.text: The image below demonstrates normal lung volumes and capacities. Which of the following changes is unlikely in a “pink puffer”?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1+2+3 is decreased

 

In a “pink puffer” (emphysema dominant COPD), total lung capacity (1+2+3) is not decreased; rather, it is typically increased due to air trapping and hyperinflation. Options A, C, and D describe findings consistent with emphysema (increased residual volume, increased FRC, and decreased vital capacity with inspiratory reserve volume).

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. 2 is increased: Functional residual capacity (FRC) is increased in pink puffers.

 

Option C. 5 is increased: Residual volume (RV) is increased due to air trapping.

 

Option C. 1+3+4 is decreased: Inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes and vital capacity (inspiratory reserve + tidal + expiratory reserve) are decreased due to hyperinflation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HRCT thorax

 

HRCT thorax provides detailed imaging to detect subtle lung pathology such as small tumors or bronchiectasis not visible on plain X-rays, making it the best next step for evaluating hemoptysis with normal X-ray. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MRI: Less sensitive and not the first-line investigation for lung parenchyma evaluation. 

 

Option B. Fiberoptic bronchoscopy: Useful after imaging to localize bleeding source but not first step with normal X-ray. 

 

Option D. Rigid bronchoscopy: More invasive and used mainly for therapeutic interventions or severe bleeding.

questions.text: A 45 year old patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoventilation causes hypoxemia with a normal or low A-a gradient because both alveolar and arterial oxygen levels decrease proportionally without mismatch or shunting. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: Leads to increased A-a gradient due to blood bypassing ventilated alveoli. 

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: Increases A-a gradient because of uneven ventilation-perfusion. 

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: Causes diffusion impairment and increased A-a gradient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a positive vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is the first-line treatment for patients with pulmonary hypertension who have a positive vasoreactivity response. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Iloprost: Used as a prostacyclin analog for severe cases, not initial therapy after a positive vasoreactivity test. 

 

Option B. Ambrisentan: An endothelin receptor antagonist used for pulmonary hypertension but not first for vasoreactive patients. 

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Reserved for advanced pulmonary hypertension refractory to other treatments.

questions.text: A patient in emergency admitted to ICU based on the appropriate score with the following CXR presentation. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The chest X-ray demonstrates consolidation of the right lower lobe, a classic finding for community-acquired pneumonia in a hospitalized patient. The recommended treatment of choice for severe community-acquired pneumonia requiring ICU admission is the combination of a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) plus a macrolide (e.g., azithromycin), which provides broad coverage including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical organisms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Mechanical ventilation: Indicated only if respiratory failure is present, not routinely for pneumonia with adequate gas exchange.

 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Not adequate for severe, hospitalized patients or ICU admission.

 

Option D. LMW heparin: Used for prevention/treatment of thromboembolism, not for pneumonia.

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

The image compares normal and patient spirometry curves, showing a greater reduction in FEV1 than FVC in the patient, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This pattern is characteristic of obstructive lung disease, such as bronchiectasis, where airway damage impairs rapid expiration.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: Usually causes a restrictive pattern with proportionately reduced FVC and FEV1, not an isolated drop in FEV1.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis:Typically produces a restrictive pattern, not obstructive spirometry changes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Also presents as restrictive disease with reduced lung volumes but a relatively preserved FEV1/FVC ratio.

choices.text: Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction
Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night
Episodes of apnea increase work of breathing
PaO2 is normal during the day

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness, and his wife also complains that he snores a lot at night during sleep. Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction

 

In obstructive sleep apnea, decreased tone (not increased) of pharyngeal muscles worsens airway obstruction during sleep. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night: Correct; hypoxia causes arousals to restore airflow. 

 

Option C. Episodes of apnea increase work of breathing: True; repeated apneas increase respiratory effort. 

 

Option C. PaO2 is normal during the day: Daytime oxygen levels often normalize despite nocturnal hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

 

Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that helps liquefy thick sputum by breaking down mucus, improving clearance. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: Combining an antitussive with a mucolytic is less appropriate for productive cough. 

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: An antitussive not recommended with productive cough due to sputum retention risk. 

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Suppresses cough reflex; not ideal when sputum clearance is needed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of exertional dyspnea and dry cough for 8 months. Oxygen saturation on room air while lying down is 96% and drops to 88% after 6 minutes of walking. Examination shows fine crackles in both lower lungs. Chest x-ray reveals reticular densities in both lung fields. Lung biopsy shows an infiltration of inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes, as well as poorly formed noncaseating granulomas and moderate alveolar septal fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

 

The presence of lymphocytic infiltration, noncaseating granulomas, and fibrosis with exertional desaturation suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to repeated antigen exposure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Characterized by reversible airway obstruction, not fibrosis or granulomas. 

 

Option B. Chronic bronchitis: A clinical diagnosis with mucus hypersecretion, not granulomatous inflammation. 

 

Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Usually shows usual interstitial pneumonia pattern without granulomas.

choices.text: Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure increased, lymphatic flow normal
Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow decreased
Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow increased
Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure decreased, lymphatic flow increased

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to worsening dyspnea on exertion for the past 3 months. The patient has had a nonproductive cough but no chest pain, fever, or chills. He was diagnosed with hypertension several years ago but takes no medications. Physical examination shows bilateral inspiratory crackles as well as dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Chest x-ray reveals a right-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following pleuropulmonary changes are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow increased

 

Increased hydrostatic pressure from conditions like heart failure causes pleural effusion with normal oncotic pressure and compensatory increased lymphatic flow. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vascular hydrostatic pressure increased, Oncotic pressure increased, lymphatic flow normal: Uncommon combination; oncotic pressure typically decreases in fluid accumulation. 

 

Option B. Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure normal, lymphatic flow decreased: Decreased lymphatic flow typically causes chylous or malignant effusions, not this scenario. 

 

Option D. Vascular hydrostatic pressure normal, Oncotic pressure decreased, lymphatic flow increased: Seen in hypoalbuminemia, but normally oncotic pressure is maintained in hypertension-related effusions.

choices.text: Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive, Diastase - Sensitive
Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative, Diastase  Resistant

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past few years. He has no history of smoking and works as an accountant. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion. A chest X-ray shows basilar emphysema. His liver function tests are mildly elevated. Which of the following properties correlate with the histopathology staining in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive, Diastase - Resistant 

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency-associated emphysema shows PAS-positive, diastase-resistant globules in hepatocytes. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive, Diastase – Sensitive: 

Typical of glycogen deposits, not alpha-1 antitrypsin globules. 

 

Option C. Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative, Diastase – Sensitive: 

Incorrect; these globules are PAS positive. 

 

Option C. Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative, Diastase  Resistant: Does not describe the histology of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in ascending order of their normal values

 

1. Vital capacity

2. FRC 

3. Inspiratory capacity

4. Tidal Volume
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4-2-3-1 

 

Normal lung volumes from smallest to largest are tidal volume (4), functional residual capacity (2), inspiratory capacity (3), and vital capacity (1). 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A, B, C: Incorrect sequences that do not reflect normal lung volume values.

choices.text: Add Fluticasone MDI two times a day
Shift to MDI Salmeterol two times a day

questions.text: A 24-year-old male who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented for a routine follow-up. PFT was done earlier—his FEV1 was 70%, which improved to 83% after bronchodilator nebulization. He was already on MDI Albuterol daily. On questioning, it seems like he is being symptomatic for at least 2 times per week and is waking up in the nights due to symptoms at least once per week. On examination, there are scattered rhonchi. What should be done?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add Fluticasone MDI two times a day

 

Adding inhaled corticosteroids like fluticasone is indicated for symptomatic asthma despite bronchodilator use, to control airway inflammation. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Shift to MDI Salmeterol two times a day: Long-acting beta-agonists should be combined with inhaled corticosteroids, not used alone. 

 

Option C. Add Prednisolone 10mg: Systemic steroids are for exacerbations or severe asthma, not routine step-up. 

 

Option C. Continue the current management: Current symptoms indicate treatment intensification is needed.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office due to increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 weeks. He has had a nonproductive cough for several months, which he attributes to allergies, but also notes a 9-kg unintentional weight loss over this time. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the expected physical examination finding over the right lower chest?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased tactile fremitus 

 

The chest X-ray shows extensive right-sided pleural effusion with complete opacification of the lower lung field and blunting of the costophrenic angle. On physical examination, pleural effusion typically produces decreased tactile fremitus over the affected area due to fluid preventing sound transmission through the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial breath sounds: May be heard over consolidation, not effusion.

 

Option C. Fine inspiratory crackles: Associated with interstitial fibrosis or alveolar fluid, not pleural fluid.

 

Option C. Increased resonance on percussion: Seen in pneumothorax, not pleural effusion; effusion produces dullness on percussion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with weight loss, hemoptysis and TTF-1 positivity. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenocarcinoma

 

TTF-1 (thyroid transcription factor-1) positivity is a marker commonly associated with lung adenocarcinoma and small cell carcinoma but is most classically used to identify adenocarcinoma in lung cancers. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer in smokers and non-smokers alike and often presents with weight loss and hemoptysis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Usually TTF-1 negative; more commonly shows keratinization and intercellular bridges.

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: May be TTF-1 positive but typically presents with rapid progression and different histopathology.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: Typically lacks TTF-1 expression and has a less differentiated histology.

questions.text: What is the route of dissemination of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematogeneous

 

The lung specimen shows multiple millet-sized nodules throughout the parenchyma, classic for miliary tuberculosis. This pattern results from hematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, spreading the infection widely via the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Air-borne: Airborne transmission is the mode of initial infection, not the cause of disseminated miliary disease.

 

Option B. Feco-oral: Not applicable for tuberculosis or miliary spread.

 

Option C. Droplet: Droplet transmission applies to some respiratory infections but not the disseminated spread of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is referred for evaluation because of hematuria and haemoptysis since 2 weeks. DLCO is 120% of normal with normal lung volumes. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis causing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. Elevated DLCO suggests alveolar hemorrhage due to increased carbon monoxide uptake. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pulmonary hypertension: Does not cause hematuria and usually lowers DLCO. 

 

Option B. Asthma: Causes airway obstruction, not hematuria or hemoptysis. 

 

Option C. Wegener’s granulomatosis: Also causes hematuria and hemoptysis but typically associated with granulomas and elevated c-ANCA, which differentiates it from microscopic polyangiitis.

questions.text: 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever, chills, productive cough. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air when lying on his right side but drops to 89% when he lies on his left. Dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds are present on the left side. Imaging is shown here. Which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms in the left lung is most responsible for the drop in oxygen saturation after the change in position?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intrapulmonary shunting

 

This patient's chest X-ray reveals left-sided consolidation, and clinical examination confirms findings of pneumonia with dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds on the left. When the patient lies on his left side (affected side down), more blood flows to poorly ventilated/consolidated regions, resulting in intrapulmonary shunting—blood passes through non-aerated parts of the lung without gas exchange, causing a drop in oxygen saturation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dead space ventilation: Refers to ventilation of non-perfused alveoli, which is not the primary issue in consolidation.

 

Option B. Effort dependent hypoventilation: No evidence is provided for effort-dependent issues; hypoxemia is positional and related to lung pathology.

 

Option C. Hypoxic vasoconstriction: May occur, but the shunt effect dominates in severe consolidation

choices.text: FEV1 low, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low
FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC high
FEV1 high, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low
FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC low

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the OPD with reports of dyspnea on exertion and decreased exercise tolerance. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has no history of childhood asthma or cough. The patient has gained almost 30kg over the past 4 years due to a sedentary lifestyle. He currently has a BMI of 41 kg/m2. His respiratory rate is 22/min and pulse oximetry is 93% on room air at rest. Physical examination is notable for central obesity. Lungs are clear on auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following changes are most likely to be seen on pulmonary function testing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1 low, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low 

 

Obesity causes a restrictive pattern in PFTs with decreased FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity (TLC), while residual volume (RV) typically remains normal.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC high: Typical of obstructive lung disease, not obesity-related restriction.

 

Option C. FEV1 high, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low: An uncommon pattern; FEV1 usually decreases alongside FVC in restriction.

 

Option D. FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC low: Increased RV is unusual in pure restrictive conditions like obesity.

questions.text: All of the following are true about theophylline except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deactivation of histone deacetylase: Anti-inflammatory

 

Theophylline actually activates histone deacetylase, which contributes to its anti-inflammatory effects; deactivation would be incorrect.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. PDE 4 inhibition: Bronchodilation: Correct, PDE4 inhibition leads to bronchodilation in airway smooth muscles.

 

Option C. PDE 3 inhibition: Cardiac effects: True, PDE3 inhibition affects cardiac contractility and heart rate.

 

Option D. Adenosine antagonism: Diuresis: Correct; blocking adenosine receptors promotes diuresis.

questions.text: 65-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnoea & pulmonary function testing was done. FEV1 is 2.5 L (78% predicted), FVC is 4.00 L (94% predicted), and the FEV1/FVC ratio is 62.5%. The flow-volume curve is shown. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subglottic stenosis

 

The flow-volume curve shows flattening of both the expiratory and inspiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed upper airway obstruction like subglottic stenosis. This pattern differs from the scooped-out expiratory limb seen in obstructive lung diseases and variable flattening seen in vocal cord paralysis or aspiration.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Aspirated foreign body: Typically causes a focal obstruction, not the fixed pattern seen here.

 

Option B. U/L vocal cord paralysis: Produces variable extrathoracic obstruction, with inspiratory flattening.

 

Option D. COPD: Leads to a concave or "scooped-out" expiratory limb, not the fixed flattening throughout the curve.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe epigastric pain and nausea. She has a 20-year history of alcohol use disorder. Nine hours after admission, she becomes increasingly dyspneic and tachypneic. Pulse oximetry on supplemental oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Physical examination shows diffuse lung crackles, marked epigastric tenderness, and a periumbilical hematoma. Laboratory studies show normal brain natriuretic peptide. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following pathomechanisms best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alveolocapillary membrane leakage

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), characterized by alveolocapillary membrane leakage leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Intrapulmonary left-to-right shunt: Does not cause hypoxemia and bilateral lung opacities as seen here. 

 

Option C. Increased production of surfactant: Surfactant production is typically decreased in ARDS, worsening lung compliance.
