Option D. Embolic obstruction of pulmonary arteries: Pulmonary embolism usually presents with sudden chest pain and localized infarction, not diffuse bilateral opacities.

questions.text:
A woman came in with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and difficulties in concentration and memory persisting for a year. During the examination, her Body Mass Index (BMI) was measured at 43 kg/m2, and her blood pressure (BP) was recorded as 170/98 mmHg. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) analysis was performed while she was awake, and the results are as follows. Based on the provided information, what is the probable diagnosis?

 

PaO2 – 70 mmHg

 

PaCO2 – 53 mmHg

 

HCO3- - 33 mmHg
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome 

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome presents with daytime hypercapnia (elevated PaCO2), hypoxemia, and metabolic compensation (elevated HCO3-) due to chronic hypoventilation in obese patients. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Typically presents with intermittent nocturnal hypoxia but normal daytime blood gases. 

 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by cessation of respiratory effort during sleep, less common in obesity. 

 

Option D. Narcolepsy: A sleep disorder presenting with excessive daytime sleepiness but without blood gas abnormalities.

questions.text: The combined compliance of the lung and chest wall of a healthy individual is measured and plotted as shown below. It is noted that the intrapleural pressure at the end of maximal inspiration is -8 cm H20 (marked x). Which of the following is the best estimate of the intrapleural pressure at the point marked by the black dot?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) -5cm H20

 

At the point marked by the black dot, which represents normal end-expiratory or functional residual capacity (FRC), the intrapleural pressure is approximately -5 cm H₂O. This negative pressure keeps the lung expanded and prevents collapse.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. +10 cm H₂O: This would indicate a highly positive pressure, which does not occur physiologically within the pleural space.

 

Option B. +5 cm H₂O: Pleural pressure is not positive in normal respiratory physiology at FRC.

 

Option D. 0 cm H₂O: Occurs with tension pneumothorax or lung collapse, not at equilibrium in a healthy individual.

questions.text: Physicians conduct a series of animal experiments to determine pulmonary tissue regeneration capacity. During one of the experiments, lung alveoli are exposed to NO2 and massive necrosis of the epithelial lining ensues. Histologic examination of the injured tissues a month later shows partial recovery of the alveolar epithelial lining. This regenerated tissue is most likely derived from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Label B marks type II pneumocytes, which function as the stem cells of the alveolar epithelium. After injury, type II pneumocytes proliferate and differentiate into type I pneumocytes, regenerating the alveolar lining and restoring epithelial integrity.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. A: Type I pneumocytes—flattened cells involved in gas exchange and cannot regenerate the epithelium.

 

Option C. C: Alveoli represented by empty air filled space

 

Option D. D: Capillary endothelial cells, play a role in gas exchange but not in epithelial regeneration.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman has been enrolled in a longitudinal research study on aging for the last 30 years. Medical history is significant for osteoporosis; she has developed moderate kyphosis due to gradual loss of vertebral body height. She is otherwise active and healthy with no additional medical issues. She has never smoked. Compared to her physiology testing done years ago, which of the following changes is most consistent with normal aging in 1) lung compliance, 2) total respiratory system compliance and 3) physiologic dead space respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase, decrease, increase

 

With aging, lung compliance increases due to loss of elastic tissue, but total respiratory system compliance decreases because of chest wall stiffening. Physiologic dead space increases due to changes in ventilation-perfusion matching.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase, increase, increase: Incorrect; total respiratory system compliance decreases with age due to chest wall changes.

 

Option C. Increase, unchanged, decrease: Incorrect; total compliance does not remain unchanged and dead space tends to increase.

 

Option D. Decrease, decrease, increase: Incorrect; lung compliance increases, not decreases, with aging.

 

Concept of lung compliance is important in OLD and RLD:

choices.text: Blood loss from hypertrophied pulmonary arteries
Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage due to vasculitis
Formation of a fistula between the tracheobronchial tree and aorta

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to hemoptysis and severe respiratory distress. The patient has been on several oral antibiotics for pneumonia over the past week and has required numerous similar treatments in the past. Pulmonary examination reveals diffusely reduced air flow, rales, and intercostal retractions. Despite aggressive management, the patient ultimately expires. An autopsy is performed and a gross lung specimen is shown in the image below:

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's hemoptysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bleeding from hypertrophied bronchial arteries

 

The gross lung specimen reveals extensive cystic changes and dilated airways, consistent with advanced bronchiectasis. In this condition, repeated infections cause hypertrophy of the bronchial arteries, which are the usual source of significant hemoptysis in affected patients.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Blood loss from hypertrophied pulmonary arteries: Pulmonary arteries do not typically hypertrophy or bleed in bronchiectasis; hemoptysis from pulmonary arteries is less common.

 

Option C. Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage due to vasculitis: This presents with diffuse infiltrates and is associated with conditions like Goodpasture's or Wegener's, not the cystic bronchiectatic changes seen here.

 

Option D. Formation of a fistula between the tracheobronchial tree and aorta: Extremely rare and would present acutely, not with chronic pulmonary changes.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High

 

Recent surgery and unilateral leg swelling contribute significantly to the Well’s score, placing the patient at high risk for pulmonary embolism even without other symptoms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Low: Incorrect; postoperative leg swelling increases risk.

 

Option C. Moderate: Risk is higher due to surgery and symptoms.

 

Option D. Cannot comment without d-dimer values: Well’s score risk stratification does not require d-dimer for initial assessment.

 

Wells Score for Pulmonary Embolism

 

 

Interpretation

 

  • Low Risk: < 2 points
  • Intermediate Risk: 2–6 points
  • High Risk: > 6 points
  • PE unlikely: 0–4 points
  • PE likely: > 4 points

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent transient pulmonary infiltrates. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma and has had several exacerbations over the past few years, particularly during the winter months. Her medications include albuterol as needed and medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoids. Complete blood count shows eosinophilia. A chest CT scan reveals proximal bronchiectasis. This patient's condition is most likely related to colonization with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) occurs in asthmatics and causes proximal bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and recurrent infiltrates due to hypersensitivity to Aspergillus colonization.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adenovirus: Not typically associated with bronchiectasis or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Strongyloides: Causes eosinophilia but not bronchiectasis or recurrent infiltrates.

 

Option D. Paragonimus: Can cause pulmonary symptoms but not characteristic proximal bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital due to perforated appendicitis. The patient quickly develops respiratory difficulty, and acute respiratory distress syndrome is diagnosed. She is intubated and mechanically ventilated with positive pressure ventilation. She is intermittently placed in the prone position while mechanically ventilated. Which of the following is most likely to occur due to this position change?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Improved ventilation-perfusion matching

 

Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, improving oxygenation by reducing lung compression and enhancing ventilation-perfusion matching in ARDS patients.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Alveolar hyperdistention: Not typically associated with prone positioning; often minimized by lung-protective ventilation.

 

Option B. Decreased cardiac output: May occur but is generally outweighed by oxygenation benefits.

 

Option C. Decreased functional residual capacity: Prone position tends to maintain or improve functional residual capacity.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is admitted for fever, cough, and malaise for the past two days. She has no history of sick contacts, and all her immunizations are up to date. Her leukocyte count is 21,000/mm with 7% band forms. Upright chest x-ray findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely location of the pathologic process in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right upper lobe 

 

The upright lateral chest x-ray demonstrates loss of normal translucency in the right upper lobe. The consolidation and opacification seen here, especially in the upper region of the lung on lateral projection, is most consistent with pneumonia affecting the right upper lobe.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Left lower lung lobe: The opacity is not localized to the left lower lobe; the left lung appears relatively clear in this view.

 

Option B. Left pleural space: There is no evidence of pleural fluid or a pleural-based abnormality on the left side.

 

Option C. Right middle lung lobe: The middle lobe occupies a different area on lateral film and would not cause this upper zone opacity.

questions.text: 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He is comatose and unable to provide any information. Multiple blunt injuries of the torso and abdomen are present. Review of the patient's medical record reveals a history of right upper lobe cavitary tuberculosis that was effectively treated several years ago. A representative slice of the chest CT, shown in the image below, redemonstrates his known right upper lobe cavity. Which of the following best describes this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic colonization

 

The presence of a pre-existing lung cavity from prior tuberculosis is a common site for chronic colonization by fungi such as Aspergillus, forming a fungus ball (aspergilloma) without tissue invasion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Allergic inflammation: Refers to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which involves airway inflammation, not colonization of a cavity.

 

Option C. Invasive malignancy: Would show a mass with tissue invasion and destruction, not a noninvasive fungus ball.

 

Option D. Heterotopic calcification: Refers to abnormal calcification of soft tissues, unrelated to lung cavities.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a head injury from a car accident was brought to the emergency department by ambulance. On exam, she had a respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, and a prolonged duration of inhalation was noted. Damage to which of the following groups of neurons in the brainstem is most likely responsible for this abnormal respiration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumotaxic center 

 

The pneumotaxic center regulates the rate and pattern of breathing by limiting inspiration duration; damage leads to prolonged inhalation and decreased respiratory rate. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dorsal respiratory group: Controls basic rhythm of inspiration but not inspiratory duration specifically. 

 

Option B. Nucleus tractus solitarius: Processes sensory information related to respiration but not direct control of breathing pattern. 

 

Option D. Vasomotor center: Regulates blood pressure and vascular tone, unrelated to respiration.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He is found to have a laceration of the spleen and is taken for emergent laparotomy. During surgery, the patient goes into cardiac arrest and dies, despite aggressive resuscitation efforts. Autopsy examination is performed and shows areas of thickening inside the chest wall as shown below. Lung examination shows fibrosis of the lower lobes. Pathologic examination of these fibrotic areas is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferruginous bodies

 

The thickening of the chest wall and lower lobe pulmonary fibrosis in the autopsy suggests asbestosis. Ferruginous bodies, iron-coated asbestos fibers, are characteristic histologic findings in asbestosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Alveolar hyaline membranes: Found in diffuse alveolar damage/acute respiratory distress syndrome, not chronic fibrosis from asbestos.

 

Option B. Birefringent silicate particles: Seen in silicosis caused by inhalation of silica dust.

 

Option C. Carbon-laden macrophages: Found in coal workers’ pneumoconiosis or anthracosis, related to coal dust exposure.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the OPD due to exertional dyspnea and cough. His symptoms started 6 months ago and have progressively worsened. Other medical conditions include peptic ulcer disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. The patient had taken a medication for rheumatoid arthritis for many years but stopped a year ago, as the drug failed to improve his worsening hand arthritis. Chest x-ray is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's pulmonary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary fibrosis

 

The patient's gradual onset exertional dyspnea, dry cough, history of rheumatoid arthritis, and chest X-ray findings suggest pulmonary fibrosis, which is a common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and can cause progressive restrictive lung disease.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Bilateral atelectasis: Would present acutely with volume loss and more focal x-ray changes, not progressive symptoms.

 

Option B. Left ventricular failure: Causes pulmonary edema with signs of cardiomegaly and vascular redistribution on X-ray.

 

Option C. Obstructive lung disease: Characterized by hyperinflation and airway obstruction, typically seen in COPD or asthma, not fibrosis.

choices.text: Compliance low, FRC high, Airway resistance high
Compliance low, FRC low, Airway resistance high
Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance high
Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance low

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy born at 29 weeks gestation via cesarean delivery due to maternal preeclampsia with severe features, is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory failure. Which of the following best describes the condition of this patient's lungs compared to a normal neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compliance low, FRC low, Airway resistance high 

 

Premature neonates typically have decreased lung compliance and lower functional residual capacity (FRC) due to immature surfactant production. Airway resistance is increased due to smaller airway caliber and immature lung structure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Compliance low, FRC high, Airway resistance high: FRC is usually low, not high, in preterm infants. 

 

Option C. Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance high: Compliance is typically low in premature lungs. 

 

Option D. Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance low: Both compliance and FRC are decreased in premature infants with respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with asthma is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and wheezing for 20 minutes. She is unable to speak more than a few words at a time. Treatment with high-dose continuous inhaled albuterol is begun. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypokalemia

 

Beta-2 agonists like albuterol drive potassium into cells, causing hypokalemia as a common adverse effect during high-dose or continuous treatment. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Miosis: Not associated with beta-2 agonist use. 

 

Option B. Hypoglycemia: Beta-2 agonists can cause hyperglycemia due to glycogenolysis. 

 

Option D. Bradycardia: Beta-2 agonists more commonly cause tachycardia, not bradycardia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with headache, fatigue, fever, and a persistent dry cough. She reports that the symptoms began 2 weeks ago during a school trip. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory testing shows hemolytic anemia with elevated reticulocyte count. Blood samples drawn into anticoagulated tubes are stored on ice, and visible clumping is observed when cold. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae 

 

Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can cause atypical pneumonia with diffuse interstitial infiltrates and cold agglutinin autoimmune hemolytic anemia, as indicated by clumping of red cells at cold temperatures. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Legionella pneumophila: Causes severe atypical pneumonia but not associated with cold agglutinins. 

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Typically causes lobar pneumonia, not interstitial infiltrates. 

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Associated with bacterial pneumonia but not cold agglutinin hemolytic anemia.

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: Physiologists studying hemoglobin function in patients with respiratory disorders are evaluating changes associated with oxygen loading and unloading. During the transition from point 1 to point 2 on the graph shown below, hemoglobin molecules are most likely to release which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Protons 

 

During oxygen unloading (from point 1 to point 2 on the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve), hemoglobin releases protons (H+), which contribute to the Bohr effect facilitating oxygen release in tissues. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Chloride: Chloride ions (chloride shift) enter red blood cells during CO2 transport but are not directly released during oxygen unloading. 

 

Option B. Oxygen: Oxygen is released by hemoglobin, but the question asks which molecule is released by hemoglobin apart from oxygen during this transition. 

 

Option C. Phosphate: Phosphate 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate binds to deoxygenated hemoglobin but is not released during oxygen unloading.

choices.text: Promotes high lung volumes for efficient gas exchange

questions.text: All are advantages of the Hering-Breuer reflex, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promotes high lung volumes for efficient gas exchange

 

The Hering-Breuer reflex primarily prevents overinflation and regulates breathing depth; it does not promote high lung volumes.

 

Hering–Breuer Reflex

 

  1. Overstretched lungs
    ↓
  2. Stretch receptors
    (Visceral pleura, bronchi, alveoli)
    ↓ Impulses through vagus nerve
  3. Respiratory center
    (Inhibits inspiratory center)
    ↓
  4. Inspiration is stopped

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Prevents overinflation during deep inspiration: True; reflex inhibits inspiration when lung stretch receptors are activated.

 

Option C. Prevents atelectasis during expiration: Reflex maintains adequate lung volume by controlling expiration.

 

Option D. Reduces unnecessary energy expenditure: Helps optimize breathing effort by modulating respiratory rhythm.

questions.text: All of the following increase lung compliance, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inspiration

 

Inspiration decreases lung compliance temporarily because the lung tissue is stretched; lung compliance is measured during passive expiration.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pulmonary emphysema: Destroys elastic tissue causing increased compliance.

 

Option B. Normal aging: Loss of elastic recoil increases lung compliance.

 

Option D. Saline-filled lung inflation: Eliminates air-liquid interface surface tension thus increasing compliance.

choices.text: Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluoroquinolones
Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene

questions.text: For MDR-RR TB, what is the indication of short course bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resistance to rifampicin and sensitive to fluoroquinolones

 

Short course bedaquiline is indicated for multidrug-resistant rifampicin-resistant TB strains that remain sensitive to fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Extrapulmonary TB like tubercular meningitis: Bedaquiline is not the first choice in meningitis due to poor CNS penetration.

 

Option C. Mutation only to INH A and kat G gene: This scenario indicates isoniazid resistance but rifampicin sensitivity; bedaquiline is targeted at rifampicin resistance.

 

Option D. Rifampicin sensitive: Standard first-line therapy is preferred for rifampicin-sensitive TB.

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morbid obesity

 

Morbid obesity causes a restrictive pattern on spirometry characterized by reduced lung volumes with preserved flow rates, resulting in a flow-volume curve with decreased volumes but relatively normal shape, consistent with restriction rather than obstruction.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy: Typically produces variable extrathoracic obstruction with flattening of the inspiratory limb on flow-volume curve.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Shows obstructive pattern with reduced expiratory flow and scooped-out appearance of the curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: An obstructive pattern characterized by reduced flow rates and increased lung volumes with a concave expiratory limb.

choices.text: Filling defect in PA on CTPA

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she collapsed suddenly while standing. She also reports left-sided chest pain. The patient was recently diagnosed with colon cancer on a routine colonoscopy and has been on bed rest since then. Her blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min and regular. Pulse oximetry shows 80% on room air. She is diaphoretic and tachypneic. Jugular venous pressure is 13 cm HO. Further workup in this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Filling defect in PA on CTPA

 

The clinical picture suggests massive pulmonary embolism, and a filling defect in the pulmonary artery on computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) confirms the diagnosis. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cannon a waves on JVP: Typically seen in complete heart block or AV dissociation, not specific here. 

 

Option B. Raised troponin levels: May occur due to RV strain but are nonspecific and secondary findings. 

 

Option C. Mediastinal widening: More suggestive of aortic dissection, not pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a 35 pack-year history of smoking presented for a routine check-up. His brother was diagnosed with lung cancer at a similar age. Which of the following would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low dose CT 

 

Low dose CT is the preferred screening modality for high-risk individuals due to its sensitivity in detecting early lung cancers with reduced radiation exposure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. High resolution CT: Used primarily for interstitial lung diseases, not screening. 

 

Option B. Chest X-Ray: Less sensitive and not recommended for lung cancer screening. 

 

Option C. CECT: Higher radiation dose and contrast use; not preferred for routine screening.
